subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: Cedric, From the point of view of an individual test run, it may not matter whether resources are obtained in the constructor or via setUp/tearDown. From the
messageBody:
Cedric,

From the point of view of an individual test run, it may not matter
whether resources are obtained in the constructor or via
setUp/tearDown.

From the point of view of a suite, it does.

A resource initialized in the test class constructor will be built
before any of the tests run, so that if you have a large suite, there
may be many objects initialized but unused until the runner starts
running the suite. This could be significant if the objects are
costly in terms of memory or some other contended resource.

With setUp/tearDown, the objects used by a test method are created and
released when the test is *run*, rather than when the test object is
constructed.

Another poster made the point that the test runner may hold onto the
test objects, so they will not be released until JUnit is exited.

Jeffrey Miller
San Francisco, CA
